attributes.title: Teaching course on methods in psychology - Technische Universität Dresden
attributes.description: Here I provide all preregistrations that have been created during my course on psychology methods.

q1.value: The road to the glass cliff: Differences in the perceived suitability of men and women for leadership positions in succeeding and failing organizations – A Replication Study.

q2.value: Denise Dörfel, Anke Richter, Anna Kaufer, Annelie Mekelburg, Clara Freitag, Johanna Hohlefeld, Martina Dulik, Anna Brückner, Caroline Petrick, Emma Maihöfer, Isabelle Engel, Justin Hänsch, Mathilde Süß, Dana van Deel, Eddy Rother, Klara Thürkow, Malina Maria Schlösser, Nadim Tatari, Monaf Zarour

q3.value:
As part of the BA in psychology at Technische Universität Dresden (module psychology methods) we replicate the following study: Haslam, S.A. & Ryan, M.K. (2008).
The road to the glass cliff: Differences in the perceived suitability of men and women for leadership positions in succeeding and failing organizations, The Leadership Quarterly 19 (2008) 530–546.

q4.value:
Compared to an equally qualified male candidate, a female candidate will be seen as more appointable to a leadership position for a festival whose popularity was declining (and involved an increased risk of failure) than for a festival whose popularity was improving and whose continued success seemed assured (H1).

Directional hypotheses: 
If festival popularity decreases, female candidate appears more suitable, while if festival popularity increases, male candidate appears more suitable.

Exploratory hypotheses:
Furthermore, we would like to explore a possible link between knowledge about the glass cliff phenomenon and candidate ranking as well as a possible correlation between the candidates' attractiveness and their ranking.
	
Additionally, we would also like to explore a possible link between feminist attitude and the candidates' ranking as well as a possible connection between stereotypical feminine and masculine characteristics and the experimental condition participants were randomly assigned to.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: Personnel who interact directly with the study subjects (either human or non-human subjects) will not be aware of the assigned treatments. (Commonly known as “double blind”)

q7.value: However, the participants will notice, whether they are assigned to the success or failure condition while not knowing about there being another condition.

question.value:
2 (festival performance: improving, declining) × 2 (gender of candidate: male, female) x 2 (gender of participant: male, female) design, with repeated measures on the second factor.

In order to rule out the possible confounds, the descriptions of the focal candidates (Candidates 1 and 3) were counterbalanced across conditions. 
As candidate photographs could not be counterbalanced across gender, two photographs were used for each of the focal candidates. 
Counterbalancing of gender of participants across conditions.

W : gender of candidate
R  : festival performance
C  : pictures and description of candidate, participants gender

q9.value: Randomized whether participants are assigned to condition of declining or increasing festival performance. Not completely randomized - subject gender is counterbalanced.

attributes.title: Association of quarterly prevalence of e-cigarette use with ever smoking among young adults in England: a time series analysis between 2007 and 2017

summary.value: We aim to assess the possible impact of tax rises on i) current smoking prevalence, ii) ever smoking prevalence (as an indicator of uptake), iii) quit attempts among past year smokers and iv) the success of those quit attempts. This registration includes the protocol and data frame for the analysis.

attributes.title: Mapping neurobiological mechanism of affective bias in healthy subjects

q1.value: Mapping neurobiological mechanism of affective bias in healthy subjects

q2.value: Angela M W Lam, Oliver J Robinson

q3.value:
Anxiety is one of the most common challenges in mental health worldwide. Approximately 40 million adults in the United States (Bandelow et al., 2015), 8.2 million in the UK (Remes et al., 2016) are affected by anxiety disorders. Apart from its extremely high prevalence rate, anxiety disorders also show high comorbidity with mood disorders such as depression. Around 7.8% of the people in Britain meet the diagnosis criteria for both anxiety and depression (Remes et al., 2016). Epidemiological studies also suggest that onset of these conditions can be as early during adolescence, and women are more susceptible to mood and anxiety disorders than men (McLean et al., 2011; de Lijster et al., 2017). Early development of symptoms without appropriate treatments can lead to long-lasting and severe impairments on functioning and overall quality of life in later stages of life. 

One of the core features of mood and anxiety disorders that causes symptomatic manifestation is distorted cognition. Information from the surrounding environment is twisted and distorted automatically in a negative way, for instance noticing or remembering more bad things over the good ones. This is referred to as negative bias. Negative bias in cognitive processing has been observed among many individuals with psychiatric disorders, especially mood and anxiety disorders. This is illustrated by a recently developed translational task in which anxious and depressed individuals show a bias towards interpreting ambiguous stimuli in a pessimistic light (Alyward et al., 2019). However, the underlying neural processes that drive performance on this task are unknown.

The amygdala and regions within the medial prefrontal cortex (mPFC) which respond to emotion processing have been found highly activated when depressive or anxious individuals are performing reasoning and judgement tasks (Adhikari, 2014; Tovote et al., 2015; Sah, 2017). This suggests that decision-making is somewhat influenced by emotions, and possibly explained one’s inability to mediate their responses between rewarding outcomes and aversive outcomes. As a consequence, these individuals are more likely to progressively develop the negative affective bias and generalize their negative thinking pattern in responding to events. 

Given the influence of affective bias thinking and judgements, ambiguous information processing is particularly affected. Our brain is more likely to employ a top-down approach to process ambiguous signals as prior knowledge and experiences are needed to aid resolving ambiguity in order to response. “Higher areas” of the brain such as the prefrontal cortex are highly engaged (Yoshida & Ishii, 2006; Etkin et al., 2011). Apart from that, symptomatic individuals of mood and anxiety disorders also appear to engage in emotional processing in the presence of the ambiguous stimuli as they tend to be perceived negatively (Aylward et al., 2019). This leads to pessimistic assessment of future options and then negative rumination. Positive cues become difficult to detect, accumulate and process to reach an objective, or even positive conclusion. While negative cues are manipulated internally in a much faster rate, leading to anticipation of negative outcomes, and biased responses. There have been animal models suggesting the anterior cingulate cortex (ACC), which is associated with reward anticipation, cognitive and emotional decision making is highly activated under negative affective state (Bush et al., 2002; Hales et al., 2014; Roelofs et al., 2016). Although a similar neural activation pattern in ACC may possibly be observed in human subjects due to the partial power of outcomes prediction on making judgement, little has been known about the relationship between this region and human affective bias.

Thus the purpose of this study is to therefore determine the neural basis of affective processing on the translational measure of affective bias (Aylward et al., 2019; Love et al., 2019) which has been implicated in mood and anxiety disorders. In particular, this is the baseline study of ‘normative’ processing in healthy individuals prior to testing the impact of mood anxiety disorder on this performance.

q4.value:
Objective: to investigate the underlying neural mechanism of the interaction between affective bias and information processing in healthy subjects. Building on prior behavioural work (Aylward et al., 2019; Love et al., 2019), this functional magnetic resonance imaging study aims to test the following predictions:

H1: Increased activity in amygdala, hippocampus, left insula, postcentral gyrus, regions within prefrontal cortex and inferior temporal cortex during ambiguity interpretation (relative to unambiguous stimuli). Amygdala and hippocampus have been found to be related to emotion processing, especially fear and anxiety (Carlisi and Robinson, 2018); whereas prefrontal cortex and inferior temporal cortex have be found to be associated with top-down processing and ambiguity interpretation (Zeki, 2004; Emadi and Esteky, 2013). 

H2: Increased activity in anterior cingulate cortex (both dorsal and ventral) is found during outcome presentation. ACC has been found to be highly active when making decision associated with reward and punishment anticipation (Bush et al., 2002; Hales et al., 2014). The ventral ACC seems to play a role in mediating between reward- and aversion-related emotion, and regulate the cognitive functions such as judgement and decision-making accordingly.

H3: Proportion of positive response toward ambiguity and drift rate decreases with increasing measure scores on MDD, GAD and OCD measures. Since there might be variations in effect of affective bias on cognitive processing among the healthy subjects in this study, comparisons can be made between the affective bias measure, drift rate and symptomatic measures, to determine whether if there is any effect of MDD, GAD and OCD tendency on proportion and rate of responses. 

We anticipate that our findings will be relevant for outlining the neurobiological mechanism of negative affective bias and eventually shed light on effective interventions in treating the distorted cognition of pathological individuals.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
This is a within-subjects experimental study. The experiment is based on a translational task. Participants will complete a practice block prior to the main experiment. 

In the practice block, a series of stimulus: big black circle (400 X 400) and small black circle (200 X 200) will be randomly presented to the participants. They will be asked to identify and discriminate the two circles by pressing the buttons (left or right). A correct response to the circle will result in a reward of either £1 or £4, depending on the size of the circle. The learning of reward amount to the size of the circle will be counterbalanced across participants. 

In the test block, the participants will undergo the fMRI scanning with a 1.5 Tesla MRI scanner while doing the circle discrimination task. They will be told that there will be presentations of circles of other sizes, hence choosing a closer size between the big or the small circle and the associated reward. In fact, only a new circle (300 X 300) as the ambiguous stimulus is added to the presentation of the stimuli series, and is randomly, evenly assigned with either a low or high reward. So each participant will go through 120 trials that are split into 40 big, medium and small circle trials respectively
 
The study site shall be the Institute of Cognitive Neuroscience, Alexandra House, 17 Queen’s Square, London , WC1N 3AZ and the Birkbeck-UCL Centre for Neuroimaging (BUCNI).

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value:
Prior to the experimental session participants will be told, via email, the details of the experiment and what they will have to do. 
On arrival at the study, prior to any other procedures, the experimenter shall explain in detail the nature of the experiment and the participant shall be given the opportunity to ask questions. If the participant is happy to proceed and has read the information sheet they shall sign a consent form. The researcher will keep this and give the participant a copy. 
After written consent has been obtained, a modified version of non-verbal IQ measure and STAI shall also be administered. 
Following this, participants shall complete the scanner task (see measures). Finally, the participant shall be thanked and remunerated for their participation. Each experimental session last approximately 1-2 hours.

q13.value:
The data for the current sample has already been collected across two separate studies (N=58, N=41) using the same fMRI sample. Both convenience samples exceed the required sample size.

We plan to use one sample as the exploration sample, and then use the second as a replication analysis. However, if there are substantial differences between the two samples (e.g. in participant characteristics or data quality) or if too much data is post hoc excluded (see below) then we will pool the data and analyse it as a single exploratory mega-analysis.

q14.value:
A power analysis was conducted to calculate a minimum sample size for the study. To achieve statistical power of 80%, a minimum number of 34 participants are required to detect an expected medium effect size of 0.4 of bias at α = 0.05 with a one-tailed one sample t-test. 
Inclusion criteria
•	Aged between 18-50 years
•	Good physical and psychiatric health
•	English as first language or equivalent level of fluency
•	Ability to give written informed consent as judged by the lead researcher
Exclusion criteria
•	Alcohol consumption less than 12 hours prior to the study
•	Recent use of illicit drugs 
•	Pregnancy or breastfeeding
•	Significant current or past medical or psychiatric illness
•	Strong family history of mood disorder, including panic disorder
•	Significant physical abnormality (e.g., history of cardiac or respiratory problems, including asthma)
•	Pacemaker or cochlear implants
•	Not registered with a general practitioner (GP)
•	Drinking more than 35 alcoholic units/week for females and 50 units/week for males
•	Personal history of alcoholism or drug dependence
•	Impaired or uncorrected vision or hearing
•	Colour blindness 
•	Potential, in the opinion of the investigator, to be non-compliant with the study
Participants will be told that they have no obligation to complete the study even after they enrol and may withdraw at any point without providing an explanation.

question.value: The manipulated variable in the study is "ambiguity". It is manipulated through the sizes of the circle: small, middle (ambiguous stimuli) and big.

Measured variables are the choice behaviour which is the proportion of the middle-sized circles (ambiguous stimuli) being associated and interpreted as high rewarding (affective bias), and the brain activity during the experimental tasks. Other measured variables are the mean reaction time (RT), RT variance for middle stimuli, and the scores of the modified version of non-verbal IQ measure and STAI.

Behaviour
We adopt the behavioral analysis of calculating the proportion of the middle-sized circles (ambiguous stimuli) being associated and interpreted as high rewarding (affective bias) for assessing the choice behavior. The proportion of high rewarding responses, together with the mean reaction time (RT), RT variance for middle stimuli are also fed into the EZ diffusion model with three parameters: drift rate, boundary separation and non-decision time for analysis. One sample t-tests will be used to analyse the proportion of ambiguous stimulus being interpreted as high-reward from 50% chance and the drift rate from 0, both with a significance value of p = 0.05. 

Since all participants complete the STAI and a modified version of non-verbal IQ measure and STAI correlation analysis will be conducted to study any potential relationship between the measure scores, affective bias, boundary separation and drift rate.

Neuroimaging
For statistical analysis of fMRI data, a General Linear Model (GLM) will be estimated by the onset time-locked regressors that are further convolved with the hemodynamic response function in Statistical Parametric Mapping (SPM), based on the following fMRI event-related design:

(1)	Unambiguous; high reward	
(2)	Unambiguous; low reward
(3)	Ambiguous; high reward response	
(4)	Ambiguous; low reward response

The first level analysis will contrast the (3) high-reward > (4) low-reward to ambiguous stimuli (over and above the unambiguous stimuli) in each individual separately. The second level analysis will combine these individual contrasts across individuals. One-sample t-tests will then be used to determine neural responses to determining high or low reward under ambiguity in the group. 

Both whole-brain analysis and region-based analysis will be used to analyze the task effects with significance value of p < 0.05 (corrected for multiple comparisons). According to some previous studies, multiple regions in the brain such as amygdala and striatum (Lago et al., 2017) are highly activated during emotional processing. We will therefore adopt amygdala - rDMPFC-amygdala and vPFC-amygdala (Robinson et al., 2012), and striatum ROIs (Tzourio-Mazoyer et al., 2002).

q22.value:
Post-hoc data exclusions
Participant’s data will be excluded from analysis if there are artefacts in the fMRI data (e.g. due to movement) or if they show a pattern of responding that indicates a lack of engagement with the task (e.g. no button presses, 50% accuracy on the extreme trials, consistent pressing of the same button)

q24.value: Whole-brain correlations with STAI will comprise an exploratory analysis to further investigate other possible neural substrates of anxiety and depression while performing in cognitive tasks.

q25.value:
Data Management 
Research is compliant with the relevant UK and EU Data Protection legislation. Data shall be pseudonymised by assigning an identification number to each participant. Any personally identifiable information, including mental health history, will be stored in locked filing cabinets or on a walled-garden server at UCL. 

The data controller for this project will be University College London (UCL). The UCL Data Protection Officer provides oversight of UCL activities involving the processing of personal data, and can be contacted at data-protection@ucl.ac.uk. The lawful basis that would be used to process personal data will be performance of a task in the public interest. The lawful basis used to process special category personal data will be for scientific and historical research or statistical purposes. Personal data will be processed indefinitely. If we are able to anonymise or pseudonymise the personal data provided we will undertake this, and will endeavour to minimise the processing of personal data wherever possible. 

Ethics
The study has been reviewed by the University College London Research Ethics Committee (Ethics Project ID number: 6198/002 & BUCNI-BBK-16-002). Participants will be informed of the nature of the study and the risks involved before signing up, and will be reminded again on arrival at the study. They will be able to ask the experimenter any questions. Written consent shall be obtained, and it shall be made clear that it is possible to withdraw at any time without any penalty. 

Publication Policy
The results from this research study may be published in an appropriate scientific journal, and/or presented at an appropriate meeting. Study data will be collected and held by the study investigators. The data will be made available for sharing via a University College London online data and the results of this study may also be published as part of a student thesis.

registration_responses.q4:
Objective: to investigate the underlying neural mechanism of the interaction between affective bias and information processing in healthy subjects. Building on prior behavioural work (Aylward et al., 2019; Love et al., 2019), this functional magnetic resonance imaging study aims to test the following predictions:

H1: Increased activity in amygdala, hippocampus, left insula, postcentral gyrus, regions within prefrontal cortex and inferior temporal cortex during ambiguity interpretation (relative to unambiguous stimuli). Amygdala and hippocampus have been found to be related to emotion processing, especially fear and anxiety (Carlisi and Robinson, 2018); whereas prefrontal cortex and inferior temporal cortex have be found to be associated with top-down processing and ambiguity interpretation (Zeki, 2004; Emadi and Esteky, 2013). 

H2: Increased activity in anterior cingulate cortex (both dorsal and ventral) is found during outcome presentation. ACC has been found to be highly active when making decision associated with reward and punishment anticipation (Bush et al., 2002; Hales et al., 2014). The ventral ACC seems to play a role in mediating between reward- and aversion-related emotion, and regulate the cognitive functions such as judgement and decision-making accordingly.

H3: Proportion of positive response toward ambiguity and drift rate decreases with increasing measure scores on MDD, GAD and OCD measures. Since there might be variations in effect of affective bias on cognitive processing among the healthy subjects in this study, comparisons can be made between the affective bias measure, drift rate and symptomatic measures, to determine whether if there is any effect of MDD, GAD and OCD tendency on proportion and rate of responses. 

We anticipate that our findings will be relevant for outlining the neurobiological mechanism of negative affective bias and eventually shed light on effective interventions in treating the distorted cognition of pathological individuals.
registration_responses.q5: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.
q6: No blinding is involved in this study.
registration_responses.q10: Registration prior to accessing the data
registration_responses.q13:
The data for the current sample has already been collected across two separate studies (N=58, N=41) using the same fMRI sample. Both convenience samples exceed the required sample size.

We plan to use one sample as the exploration sample, and then use the second as a replication analysis. However, if there are substantial differences between the two samples (e.g. in participant characteristics or data quality) or if too much data is post hoc excluded (see below) then we will pool the data and analyse it as a single exploratory mega-analysis.
registration_responses.q14:
A power analysis was conducted to calculate a minimum sample size for the study. To achieve statistical power of 80%, a minimum number of 34 participants are required to detect an expected medium effect size of 0.4 of bias at α = 0.05 with a one-tailed one sample t-test. 
Inclusion criteria
•	Aged between 18-50 years
•	Good physical and psychiatric health
•	English as first language or equivalent level of fluency
•	Ability to give written informed consent as judged by the lead researcher
Exclusion criteria
•	Alcohol consumption less than 12 hours prior to the study
•	Recent use of illicit drugs 
•	Pregnancy or breastfeeding
•	Significant current or past medical or psychiatric illness
•	Strong family history of mood disorder, including panic disorder
•	Significant physical abnormality (e.g., history of cardiac or respiratory problems, including asthma)
•	Pacemaker or cochlear implants
•	Not registered with a general practitioner (GP)
•	Drinking more than 35 alcoholic units/week for females and 50 units/week for males
•	Personal history of alcoholism or drug dependence
•	Impaired or uncorrected vision or hearing
•	Colour blindness 
•	Potential, in the opinion of the investigator, to be non-compliant with the study
Participants will be told that they have no obligation to complete the study even after they enrol and may withdraw at any point without providing an explanation.
registration_responses.q22:
Post-hoc data exclusions
Participant’s data will be excluded from analysis if there are artefacts in the fMRI data (e.g. due to movement) or if they show a pattern of responding that indicates a lack of engagement with the task (e.g. no button presses, 50% accuracy on the extreme trials, consistent pressing of the same button)
registration_responses.q24: Whole-brain correlations with STAI will comprise an exploratory analysis to further investigate other possible neural substrates of anxiety and depression while performing in cognitive tasks.
registration_responses.q25:
Data Management 
Research is compliant with the relevant UK and EU Data Protection legislation. Data shall be pseudonymised by assigning an identification number to each participant. Any personally identifiable information, including mental health history, will be stored in locked filing cabinets or on a walled-garden server at UCL. 

The data controller for this project will be University College London (UCL). The UCL Data Protection Officer provides oversight of UCL activities involving the processing of personal data, and can be contacted at data-protection@ucl.ac.uk. The lawful basis that would be used to process personal data will be performance of a task in the public interest. The lawful basis used to process special category personal data will be for scientific and historical research or statistical purposes. Personal data will be processed indefinitely. If we are able to anonymise or pseudonymise the personal data provided we will undertake this, and will endeavour to minimise the processing of personal data wherever possible. 

Ethics
The study has been reviewed by the University College London Research Ethics Committee (Ethics Project ID number: 6198/002 & BUCNI-BBK-16-002). Participants will be informed of the nature of the study and the risks involved before signing up, and will be reminded again on arrival at the study. They will be able to ask the experimenter any questions. Written consent shall be obtained, and it shall be made clear that it is possible to withdraw at any time without any penalty. 

Publication Policy
The results from this research study may be published in an appropriate scientific journal, and/or presented at an appropriate meeting. Study data will be collected and held by the study investigators. The data will be made available for sharing via a University College London online data and the results of this study may also be published as part of a student thesis.
registration_responses.q8.question:
This is a within-subjects experimental study. The experiment is based on a translational task. Participants will complete a practice block prior to the main experiment. 

In the practice block, a series of stimulus: big black circle (400 X 400) and small black circle (200 X 200) will be randomly presented to the participants. They will be asked to identify and discriminate the two circles by pressing the buttons (left or right). A correct response to the circle will result in a reward of either £1 or £4, depending on the size of the circle. The learning of reward amount to the size of the circle will be counterbalanced across participants. 

In the test block, the participants will undergo the fMRI scanning with a 1.5 Tesla MRI scanner while doing the circle discrimination task. They will be told that there will be presentations of circles of other sizes, hence choosing a closer size between the big or the small circle and the associated reward. In fact, only a new circle (300 X 300) as the ambiguous stimulus is added to the presentation of the stimuli series, and is randomly, evenly assigned with either a low or high reward. So each participant will go through 120 trials that are split into 40 big, medium and small circle trials respectively
 
The study site shall be the Institute of Cognitive Neuroscience, Alexandra House, 17 Queen’s Square, London , WC1N 3AZ and the Birkbeck-UCL Centre for Neuroimaging (BUCNI).
registration_responses.q12.question:
Prior to the experimental session participants will be told, via email, the details of the experiment and what they will have to do. 
On arrival at the study, prior to any other procedures, the experimenter shall explain in detail the nature of the experiment and the participant shall be given the opportunity to ask questions. If the participant is happy to proceed and has read the information sheet they shall sign a consent form. The researcher will keep this and give the participant a copy. 
After written consent has been obtained, a modified version of non-verbal IQ measure and STAI shall also be administered. 
Following this, participants shall complete the scanner task (see measures). Finally, the participant shall be thanked and remunerated for their participation. Each experimental session last approximately 1-2 hours.
registration_responses.q16.question: The manipulated variable in the study is "ambiguity". It is manipulated through the sizes of the circle: small, middle (ambiguous stimuli) and big.
registration_responses.q17.question: Measured variables are the choice behaviour which is the proportion of the middle-sized circles (ambiguous stimuli) being associated and interpreted as high rewarding (affective bias), and the brain activity during the experimental tasks. Other measured variables are the mean reaction time (RT), RT variance for middle stimuli, and the scores of the modified version of non-verbal IQ measure and STAI.
registration_responses.q19.question:
Behaviour
We adopt the behavioral analysis of calculating the proportion of the middle-sized circles (ambiguous stimuli) being associated and interpreted as high rewarding (affective bias) for assessing the choice behavior. The proportion of high rewarding responses, together with the mean reaction time (RT), RT variance for middle stimuli are also fed into the EZ diffusion model with three parameters: drift rate, boundary separation and non-decision time for analysis. One sample t-tests will be used to analyse the proportion of ambiguous stimulus being interpreted as high-reward from 50% chance and the drift rate from 0, both with a significance value of p = 0.05. 

Since all participants complete the STAI and a modified version of non-verbal IQ measure and STAI correlation analysis will be conducted to study any potential relationship between the measure scores, affective bias, boundary separation and drift rate.

Neuroimaging
For statistical analysis of fMRI data, a General Linear Model (GLM) will be estimated by the onset time-locked regressors that are further convolved with the hemodynamic response function in Statistical Parametric Mapping (SPM), based on the following fMRI event-related design:

(1)	Unambiguous; high reward	
(2)	Unambiguous; low reward
(3)	Ambiguous; high reward response	
(4)	Ambiguous; low reward response

The first level analysis will contrast the (3) high-reward > (4) low-reward to ambiguous stimuli (over and above the unambiguous stimuli) in each individual separately. The second level analysis will combine these individual contrasts across individuals. One-sample t-tests will then be used to determine neural responses to determining high or low reward under ambiguity in the group. 

Both whole-brain analysis and region-based analysis will be used to analyze the task effects with significance value of p < 0.05 (corrected for multiple comparisons). According to some previous studies, multiple regions in the brain such as amygdala and striatum (Lago et al., 2017) are highly activated during emotional processing. We will therefore adopt amygdala - rDMPFC-amygdala and vPFC-amygdala (Robinson et al., 2012), and striatum ROIs (Tzourio-Mazoyer et al., 2002).

q1.value: EEG marker for explicit prediction of auditory stimuli

q2.value: Yijie Yin, Maria Niedernhuber, Tristan Bekinschtein

q3.value: The slope of the event-related-potential (ERP) contingent negative variation (CNV) has been shown to vary according to explicit expectation (Walter 1964). CNV is present when participants pay attention to series of auditory stimuli with occasional oddballs. However, the explicit expectation has never been investigated alone. Here we use the global-local paradigm (Bekinschtein et al. 2009) to identify the EEG marker of explicit prediction by asking participants to indicate their predictions of the next sound sequence with a joystick. We will also investigate the influence of explicit expectation on P3b, as well as the interaction between saliency of global deviances and decision-making.

q5.value: Experiment - A researcher randomly assigns treatments to study subjects, this includes field or lab experiments. This is also known as an intervention experiment and includes randomized controlled trials.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value:
Global-local paradigm: 
Participants will hear series of tone sequences. There are 2 types of tones: a mixture of 3 sinusoidal signals of either 500, 1000 and 2000 Hz, or 350, 700 and 1400Hz in Matlab R2016 based on Chennu et al. (2013, 2016). Every sound sequence / trial is made of 5 tones, consisting of 4 consecutive identical tones and the 5th sound which could be either identical or different. When it is different, it is delivered in the opposite ear, with the same or a different pitch. Each tone is delivered for 50ms with a delay of 100ms between stimuli. Trials are separated by an 800ms-1000ms time interval. 

Global sequences are made of trials. Several trials of global standards are presented before a global deviant occurs. When global standard = local standard, the global standard consists of 5 identical tones; when global standard = local deviant, the global standard is where the same sound is played on the opposite ear as the 5th tone. 

For each block, after the initial presentation of 15 global standards, it is equally likely that a global deviant occurs after 2, 3, or 4 global standards. Overall, there is 73.3% possibility that the trial is a global standard, and 13.3% possibility for either type of global deviant. There are 6 2-consecutive deviants (where 2 global deviants occur consecutively; 3 for each type of deviant) and 2 3-consecutive deviants in each block. Without taking consecutive global deviants into account, there is 76.7% possibility for global standards, and 11.6% for either type of global deviant. 

This is a within-subject design study with the following conditions: 
In the first 4 blocks, participants are instructed to attend to the sounds played. Factors including the side of presentation (whether the local standards are played in the right or left ear) and block type (whether global standard = local standard) are counterbalanced; 
In blocks 5-8, participants are trained to use the joystick (both before block 5 and before block 7) to indicate to what extent they think the next trial may be a global deviant. In the first 2 blocks, moving joystick to the foremost indicates the likeliest that the next trial is a global deviant; in the last 2 blocks, moving joystick to the foremost indicates the unlikeliest. 
In block 9, no global deviants are presented. Participants are instructed to move the joystick freely while trying to 'indicate all the possibilities'. 
In the last 4 blocks, participants are instructed to attend to the same stimuli as in blocks 5-8 without using joystick.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: We will include right-handed individuals aged 18-35 with normal binaural hearing and no history of neurological or psychiatric diseases. Participants will be recruited via both the Cambridge Psychology SONA system and fliers advertising the study. They will give written and informed consent to participate in the study and receive a compensation of £10 per hour (around £30 per participant).

q13.value:
In each block, there are at least 16 standards at each lateness, half of which differ with the other in saliency. The same is true for the deviants. There are 50 1st-deviants (hereafter 'deviants'), 8 2nd-deviants and 2 3rd-deviants in each block. 
We will recruit 20 participants.

q14.value:
The number of deviants for each lateness was the primary factor that determined the length of each block. As we would like to minimise the time needed for each trial to avoid boredom of participants, as well as to maximise the power, we have 16 trials per block, 64 trials per condition (4 blocks), adhering to Luck's (2004) recommendation of 40-60 trials for an analysis of large components. 
The number of participants is primarily determined by the limit in time.

question.value:
position of the joystick right before the presentation of the 5th tone in each trial in blocks 5-9; 
EEG data in all blocks.

q22.value: We will exclude participants due to technical error, large artefacts in the EEG data and a failure of participants to understand instructions.

As we would like to minimise the time needed for each trial to avoid boredom of participants, as well as to maximise the power, we have 16 trials per block, 64 trials per condition (4 blocks), adhering to Luck's (2004) recommendation of 40-60 trials for an analysis of large components. 
The number of participants is primarily determined by the limit in time.
registration_responses.q22: We will exclude participants due to technical error, large artefacts in the EEG data and a failure of participants to understand instructions.

registration_responses.q8.question:
Global-local paradigm: 
Participants will hear series of tone sequences. There are 2 types of tones: a mixture of 3 sinusoidal signals of either 500, 1000 and 2000 Hz, or 350, 700 and 1400Hz in Matlab R2016 based on Chennu et al. (2013, 2016). Every sound sequence / trial is made of 5 tones, consisting of 4 consecutive identical tones and the 5th sound which could be either identical or different. When it is different, it is delivered in the opposite ear, with the same or a different pitch. Each tone is delivered for 50ms with a delay of 100ms between stimuli. Trials are separated by an 800ms-1000ms time interval. 

Global sequences are made of trials. Several trials of global standards are presented before a global deviant occurs. When global standard = local standard, the global standard consists of 5 identical tones; when global standard = local deviant, the global standard is where the same sound is played on the opposite ear as the 5th tone. 

For each block, after the initial presentation of 15 global standards, it is equally likely that a global deviant occurs after 2, 3, or 4 global standards. Overall, there is 73.3% possibility that the trial is a global standard, and 13.3% possibility for either type of global deviant. There are 6 2-consecutive deviants (where 2 global deviants occur consecutively; 3 for each type of deviant) and 2 3-consecutive deviants in each block. Without taking consecutive global deviants into account, there is 76.7% possibility for global standards, and 11.6% for either type of global deviant. 

This is a within-subject design study with the following conditions: 
In the first 4 blocks, participants are instructed to attend to the sounds played. Factors including the side of presentation (whether the local standards are played in the right or left ear) and block type (whether global standard = local standard) are counterbalanced; 
In blocks 5-8, participants are trained to use the joystick (both before block 5 and before block 7) to indicate to what extent they think the next trial may be a global deviant. In the first 2 blocks, moving joystick to the foremost indicates the likeliest that the next trial is a global deviant; in the last 2 blocks, moving joystick to the foremost indicates the unlikeliest. 
In block 9, no global deviants are presented. Participants are instructed to move the joystick freely while trying to 'indicate all the possibilities'. 
In the last 4 blocks, participants are instructed to attend to the same stimuli as in blocks 5-8 without using joystick.
registration_responses.q12.question: We will include right-handed individuals aged 18-35 with normal binaural hearing and no history of neurological or psychiatric diseases. Participants will be recruited via both the Cambridge Psychology SONA system and fliers advertising the study. They will give written and informed consent to participate in the study and receive a compensation of £10 per hour (around £30 per participant).
registration_responses.q17.question:
position of the joystick right before the presentation of the 5th tone in each trial in blocks 5-9; 
EEG data in all blocks.

attributes.title: The effects of different pedagogies in health progression education

q1.value: The effects of different pedagogies in health progression education

q2.value: Hong-Jie Jhou, Liang Jun, Ou Yang, Ming-Hsun Lin, Po-Huang Chen, Cho-Hao Lee

q4.value: The aim of the network meta-analysis is to assess the relative efficacy of different pedagogies in healthcare education.

q5.value: Meta-Analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: Network meta-analysis - A systematic review of published studies.

q10.value: Registration prior to accessing the data

question.value: We performed a comprehensive search without language restrictions using electronic databases including PubMed, Embase, Cochrane Central Register of Controlled Trials, Cochrane Database of Systematic Reviews, China National Knowledge Infrastructure (https://www.cnki.net), and the Web of Science from inception until July 01 2019, to identify all published and unpublished trials with screening the titles and reviewing the abstracts. We adapted the search strategy and keywords presented in supplement 2 for above databases. To ensure no missing RCTs, we conducted a hand-searching search on gray literature (conference abstract and doctoral thesis) and reference lists of included articles. For ongoing trials, we collected information from Google Scholar, the US government clinical trials database (www.ClinicalTrials.gov) and the UK National Research Register.

q13.value: The 54 trials (19 quasi-RCT, 35 RCT) investigated a total of 4,292 participants randomized to the following 8 education options

question.value:
1.Knowledge is defined as delivery of the theoretical basis of  clinical practice, measured by paper-based tests including multiple choice questions, multiple-response questions, true/false questions, key feature format questions, free-text answers, or short  answer  questions.
2.Skill is defined as the student’s ability to demonstrate clinical performance, assessed on mannequin, a live standardized patient, or virtual patients, measuring by written assignment, mix of paper cases and virtual patients, computer-based assessment, or objective structured clinical examination (OSCE).

We did a network meta-analysis using a frequentist approach and provided a point estimate from the network and a 95% CI from the frequency distribution of the estimate. All network meta-analyses were performed with the statistical package “netmeta” 0.9-0 (https://cran.r-project.org/web/packages/netmeta/index.html) in R 3.4.2 (R Core Team, Vienna, Austria) and Stata, version 14 (Stata Corp, College Station, Texas).
 We examined the symmetry and geometry of the evidence by producing a network plot with node for the study subjects. The contribution of each direct comparison to the estimation of the network summary effects was calculated according to the combination of the variance of the direct treatment effect and the network structure.
For the result of skill and knowledge, we calculated the standardized mean difference (SMD) with 95% confidence intervals (CIs). A positive SMD value indicated a greater increase in both of the outcomes.
The probability of a mode being ranked was calculated as their surface under cumulative ranking curve (SUCRA), which is the percentage of efficacy achieved by an approach compared with an imaginary approach that is always the best without uncertainty (ie, SUCRA 100%). SUCRA provides a hierarchy of treatments and accounts for variance of all relative intervention effects, the SUCRA value is 0 when a treatment is the worst option and 1 when a treatment is the best option. Higher SUCRA scores correspond to better knowledge and skill performance.18 Forest plots represent the results of NMA and summary relative mean effects, 95% confidence intervals and SUCRA for all comparisons together. We summaries values of SUCRA in the two-dimensional scatter plots, which presented the probability of being the best pedagogies in both of knowledge and skill. 
We used a multivariate random-effects meta-regression with a consistency model, as described by White and colleagues. We assessed potential inconsistencies by comparing deviance and deviance estimates for each comparison between consistency and inconsistency using random-effects design-by-treatment interaction model and node-splitting technique. Statistical significance was considered as p < 0.05 for both analyses.
Network transitivity were executed by visually inspecting tables with study-related characteristics that may modify treatment effects including difference in patient characteristics, study designs, detail of intervention and differences in measurement of outcome.
We evaluated whether treatment effects for the two outcomes were robust in multiple meta-regression and  subgroup analyses. The following effect modiﬁers were analyzed by multiple meta-regression model:  fields of disciplines, study designs, educational status, study location and assessment measurement tools. Subgroup analyses were performed with the following variables: fields of disciplines such as medicine or nursing, performing studies in east or west countries, and education scenario in cardiopulmonary or non-cardiopulmonary.
The sensitivity analyses of our conclusions were evaluated by analyzing the dataset with the following restrictions: studies without comparison of No intervention,  studies without multiple arms designs, studies with pre-graduated participants and studies without quasi/cluster RCTs. Comparison-adjusted funnel plots and the Begg’s test25 were also conducted for evaluations of publication bias and small study effects.

attributes.title: Empathy choice in Japanese people – Replication of Cameron et al. (2019)

q1.value: Empathy choice in Japanese people – Replication of Cameron et al. (2019)

q2.value: Yuta Kawamura, Naoki Konishi, Yohsuke Ohtsubo

q3.value:
We will replicate Study 1 of Cameron et al. (2019) with a Japanese non-student sample. We are particularly interested in whether the pattern of empathy avoidance is replicable in Japan.

Cameron, C. D., Hutcherson, C. A., Ferguson, A. M., Scheffer, J. A., Hadjiandreou, E., & Inzlicht, M. (2019). Empathy is hard work: People choose to avoid empathy because of its cognitive costs. Journal of Experimental Psychology: General, 148(6), 962-976. doi: 10.1037/xge0000595

q4.value: We will ask participants to choose their own task from the empathy and non-empathy tasks. We predict that the empathy choice rate is lower than 50% among a Japanese sample.

value: For studies that involve human subjects, they will not know the treatment group to which they have been assigned.

question.value: This experiment does not involve any experimental manipulation. We plan to compare the empathy choice rate against the 50%-criterion using a one-sample t test.

q9.value: We will randomize the order of each trial as the original study.

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: Participants will be recruited at a Japanese crowdsourcing service. Participants will be paid 300 yen for participation. Participants are 20-59 years old.

q13.value: Our target sample size is 56 participants.

q14.value: The sample size is same as the original study, that is, study 1 of Cameron et al. (2019). A power analysis using G*Power (Faul et al., 2007) indicated that the required sample size was 41 to attain the power of .80 with the average effect in social psychology (Cohen’s d = 0.40; Richard et al., 2003). Furthermore, the effect size of the original study measured as Hedge’s g was 0.62. The required sample size was smaller than that of the original study (i.e., 56). However, we decided to collect data from 56, instead of 41, participants in case that the original study happened to be associated with somewhat larger effect size.

q15.value: We will stop data collection when the sample reaches 56 participants.

question.value: We will ask participants to choose from the empathy and non-empathy tasks for many a series of photo stimuli (i.e., participants will decide whether to empathize a target person in each of 40 photos or to objectively describe each photo). The proportion of empathy choice is the dependent variable of this study.
To examine whether Japanese people avoid empathy, we will conduct a one-sample t test whereby the empathy choice rate will be compared against the 50%-criterion.

q21.value: We will consider p-values less than .050 as statistically significant.

q22.value: We will exclude participants whose responses include any missing data points in the Empathy Selection Task.

q24.value:
1: Participants will complete the NASA Task Load Index (Hart & Staveland, 1988). The index includes the questions about effort, aversiveness, and efficacy associated with the objective and empathy decks. We will compare the NASA Task Load scores for objective decks with the score for empathy deck. 
2: Since the data of original study (Cameron et al., 2019) is available from the Open Science Framework, we will compare our own data (i.e., Japanese data) and the original data (i.e., American data).
3: Participants will answer the Japanese Version of the Short Dark Triad (SD3-J). This scale is included for an exploratory purpose. For example, we expect that the dark triad traits may be correlated with empathy avoidance. However, we have no specific hypotheses regarding this scale at the time of preregistration.

attributes.title: Alpha power modulation by tACS : systematic Review.
attributes.description: Systematic review on tACS modulation of alpha power brain activity.

summary.value:
Systematic review on transcranial alternating current stimulation  (tACS) parameters to modulate alpha power brain activity. 

Status : Ongoing

Start date:  1/09/2019

Anticipated completion date : 29/02/2020

Stages completed of review at time of submission: 

Preliminary searches 
Piloting of the study selection process 
Formal screening of search results against eligibility criteria 
Data extraction 
Risk of bias (quality) assessment 

Stages to be completed at time of submission :

Data analysis

Organisational affiliation of the review : University of Montreal, Quebec, Canada and Center of Research of Hopital Sacre-Coeur de Montreal, Quebec, Canada. 

Funding sources/sponsors: CRSNG

Review question : What are the optimized tACS parameters for alpha power increase in healthy participants ?

Searches: OVID-MEDLINE, OVID-Embase, PsycINFO, Global health and grey litterature. FOr search strategy example on medline, see attached file. 

Participants/Population: healthy adults (18 years-old and up)

Intervention: transcranial alternating current stimulation (tACS)

Comparators/Control: Sham (tACS)

Types of study to be included : Randomized controlled trials,controlled trials (corssover or parallel design), controlled clinical trials and quasi experimental studies as long as they have a control condition or group.

Main outcome: Primary outcome is alpha power/activity modulation

Timing and effect measures : Effect measures will be by EEG or MEG data analysis post stimulation and aftereffects' period

Additional ouctome(s): 
Secondary outcomes are to assess:
   - the optimized stimulation parameters for that purpose on the ground of method of 
    stimulation, duration of effect and methodological parameters : site, montage, frequency 
    and intensity
   -Sensation reporting of  the intervention and as well as after-effects 

Data extraction (selection and coding) : The article must include original data; The article must be published in English or have been translated into
these languages; The article must include a minimum of one active intervention of tACS. The article must
include EEG/MEG measures of brain activity in the alpha range. Extraction will be made on presence of alpha power modulation, aftereffects period reported, number of electrodes, types of electrodes, size, site, frequency of stimulation and intensity.

Risk of bias (quality) assessment: Risk of bias will be completed independently by 2 reviewers following Cochrane Risk of bias tool on Covidence. These 2 reviewers will meet and discuss any discrepancies to arrive at consensus.

Strategy for data synthesis : Descriptive synthesis of the literature is planned, no meta-analysis can be performed on this topic as there is too much heterogeneity of parameters is found in identified studies for comparable data.

attributes.title: Youth engagement in research, policies and guidelines for Non-Communicable Disease (NCD) prevention- a scoping review

q1.value: Youth Engagement in research, policies and guidelines for Non-Communicable Disease (NCD) prevention- a scoping review

q3.value:
Worldwide adolescents account for 16% of the global population.  Health at this life stage has the capacity to directly influence NCD risk into adulthood. Despite this, this stakeholder group is rarely consulted on decision making affecting their health.  
This scoping review aims to investigate how adolescents are currently engaged in research, policies and guidelines for the prevention of chronic diseases and provide recommendations for how to best engage them in future research.

q4.value: Research, policies, and guidelines will be assessed against the key concepts and by qualitative content analytical techniques. The results will be reported considering gaps in the evidence for adolescent engagement in co-design and decision making related to NCD prevention and the implications of the findings will be considered within the broader context of adolescent health and NCD prevention. Since the results of our scoping review are essentially qualitative, the results will be mostly discussed in narrative form.

value: No blinding is involved in this study.

question.value: This project is a scoping review of published research as well as grey literature (policies and guidelines).

q10.value: Registration prior to creation of data

question.value: The scoping review will be informed by Arksey and O’Malley’s 6-stage framework for scoping reviews, with Levac et al.’s recommendations. Enabling a flexible and iterative approach to systematically scope and interpret a range of peer-reviewed and grey literature. The Preferred Reporting Items for Systematic reviews and Meta-Analyses extension for Scoping Reviews (PRISMA- ScR) Checklist will also be used.

attributes.title: Survey Experiment of Business Election Involvement in North Africa

q1.value: Survey Experiment of Business Election Involvement in North Africa

q8.value: Registration prior to any research activities

q15.value: This project is an online survey targeted at businesspeople in North Africa through Facebook. The survey is aimed at employees' perceptions of firm political activities, in particular with regard to the most recent legislative elections. The survey's intention is to better understand the incentives that firms in North Africa respond to when evaluating whether to engage in elections by funding parties and contributing to them in diverse ways. Facebook is used as a means of recruitment because it is both low-cost and very confidential. Compared to traditional firm surveys, this project is more interested in approximate assessments of firm's political connections as opposed to data on microeconomic performance.

q16.value: The hypotheses reflect the incentives that firms face in deciding whether to support a political party's hypothetical appeal for funds. Appeal vignettes are randomized and shown to respondents in the form of a conjoint experiment, which allows for multiple actors and appeals to be shown to each respondent. The effect to be estimated is the difference in employees' perceptions of appeals that are more or less attractive to the firm in question. In addition to the different types of appeals, which reflect both clientelistic and more reform-minded benefits that a party might bring to a firm, the hypotheses look at pre-treatment covariates that might affect the attractiveness of appeals. These include firm sectoral alignment, firm size and firms' exposure to military clients as this is a significant issue in political economy in the region.

q17.value: The hypotheses are tested by looking at the difference in reported firm response to different sets of appeals for support made by parties. These differences in outcomes can be estimated as average marginal conditional effects (AMCEs) as discussed in the relevant papers by Hainmueller et al. on conjoint survey experiments. To test effects of firm characteristics, these pre-treatment covariates are interacted with the appeal type to see how effects differ across subgroups.
